mn131:1.1.comm: A favorite of meditators, this discourse takes a distinctive set of verses as a template for explaining the aspect of meditation called vipassanā, commonly rendered “insight”; for why I use “discernment” see DN 14:1.37.5 and note. The next three discourses explain the same verses on different occasions, with MN 133 offering a complementary explanation.

mn131:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn131:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn131:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn131:2.1.eng: “I shall teach you the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night.

mn131:2.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn131:2.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn131:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

mn131:3.2.comm: To “anticipate” (paṭikaṅkhe) is not always bad. A mendicant ought to “anticipate” dangers (pāṭikaṅkhitabba, AN 4.122:1.1 = MN 67:14.2); Nālaka “anticipates” the arrival of the Buddha (patikkhaṁ, Snp 3.11:19.4); and an arahant “awaits their time” (kālaṁ kaṅkhati, SN 2.29:15.4). The verse here has a specific application in meditation, which is explained below.

mn131:3.5.comm: Here “phenomenon” (dhamma) means anything that is directly knowable (see MN 133:17.9). | The two verses run on here, as indicated by the ca linking this line with the previous.

mn131:3.6.eng: you clearly discern in every case.
mn131:3.6.comm: For tattha tattha as “in every case” see eg. DN 30:2.1.3, and compare tato tattha vipassati at Snp 5.15:4.4.

mn131:3.7.comm: At Thag 14.1:5.1, this phrase refers to the mind developed in meditation on love and compassion, while at Snp 5.19:19.1 it refers to Nibbana. In both cases, as here, it is the object of the verb, not an adverb.

mn131:3.9.eng: Today’s the day to keenly work—

mn131:3.10.eng: who knows, tomorrow may bring death!

mn131:3.11.eng: For there is no bargain to be struck

mn131:3.12.eng: with Death and his mighty horde.

mn131:3.13.eng: One who keenly meditates like this,

mn131:3.15.eng: that’s who has one fine night—

mn131:4.1.eng: And how do you run back to the past?

mn131:4.2.pli: ‘Evaṃrūpo ahosiṃ atītamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti, ‘evaṃvedano ahosiṃ atītamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti, ‘evaṃsañño ahosiṃ atītamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti, ‘evaṃsaṅkhāro ahosiṃ atītamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti, ‘evaṃviññāṇo ahosiṃ atītamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti—
mn131:4.2.eng: You muster delight there, thinking: ‘I had such form in the past.’ … ‘I had such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the past.’
mn131:4.2.comm: Samanvāneti is unique in early Pali, but the similar samānayi is found at DN 30:1.33.4 and Thig 12.1:10.2 in the sense of “reunite, bring together”. “Muster” means both to bring together and to arouse. | SN 22.79 makes it clear that “in the past” means “in a past life”.

mn131:4.3.eng: That’s how you run back to the past.

mn131:5.1.eng: And how do you not run back to the past?

mn131:5.2.pli: ‘Evaṃrūpo ahosiṃ atītamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti, ‘evaṃvedano ahosiṃ atītamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti, ‘evaṃsañño ahosiṃ atītamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti, ‘evaṃsaṅkhāro ahosiṃ atītamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti, ‘evaṃviññāṇo ahosiṃ atītamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti—
mn131:5.2.eng: You don’t muster delight there, thinking: ‘I had such form in the past.’ … ‘I had such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the past.’

mn131:5.3.eng: That’s how you don’t run back to the past.

mn131:6.1.eng: And how do you anticipate the future?

mn131:6.2.pli: ‘Evaṃrūpo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti, evaṃvedano siyaṃ …pe… evaṃsañño siyaṃ … evaṃsaṅkhāro siyaṃ … evaṃviññāṇo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti—
mn131:6.2.eng: You muster delight there, thinking: ‘May I have such form in the future.’ … ‘May I have such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the future.’

mn131:6.3.eng: That’s how you anticipate the future.

mn131:7.1.eng: And how do you not anticipate the future?

mn131:7.2.pli: ‘Evaṃrūpo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti, evaṃvedano siyaṃ … evaṃsañño siyaṃ … evaṃsaṅkhāro siyaṃ … ‘evaṃviññāṇo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānan’ti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti—
mn131:7.2.eng: You don’t muster delight there, thinking: ‘May I have such form in the future.’ … ‘May I have such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the future.’

mn131:7.3.eng: That’s how you don’t anticipate the future.

mn131:8.1.eng: And how do you falter amid presently arisen phenomena?
mn131:8.1.comm: Dhammesu (“phenomena”) is plural here, whereas in the verse it is singular. Sanskrit fragments, however, have plural in the verse as well.

mn131:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
mn131:8.2.eng: It’s when an unlearned ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

mn131:8.3.pli: rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ, attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ;
mn131:8.3.eng: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

mn131:8.7.pli: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ attani vā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ—
mn131:8.7.eng: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

mn131:8.8.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, paccuppannesu dhammesu saṃhīrati.
mn131:8.8.eng: That’s how you falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

mn131:9.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati?
mn131:9.1.eng: And how do you not falter amid presently arisen phenomena?

mn131:9.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako ariyānaṃ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto sappurisānaṃ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto
mn131:9.2.eng: It’s when a learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.

mn131:9.3.pli: na rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, na rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ, na attani vā rūpaṃ, na rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ;
mn131:9.3.eng: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

mn131:9.7.pli: na viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, na viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ, na attani vā viññāṇaṃ, na viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ—
mn131:9.7.eng: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

mn131:9.8.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati.
mn131:9.8.eng: That’s how you don’t falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

mn131:10.6.eng: you clearly discern in every case.

mn131:10.9.eng: Today’s the day to keenly work—

mn131:10.10.eng: who knows, tomorrow may bring death!

mn131:10.11.eng: For there is no bargain to be struck

mn131:10.12.eng: with Death and his mighty horde.

mn131:10.13.eng: One who keenly meditates like this,

mn131:10.15.eng: that’s who has one fine night—

mn131:11.1.eng: And that’s what I meant when I said: ‘I shall teach you the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night.’”

mn131:11.2.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttan”ti.

mn131:11.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn131:11.4.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn131:11.4.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

mn132:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn132:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn132:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ānando upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca bhāsati.
mn132:2.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dhamma talk on the topic of the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night.

mn132:2.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenupaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
mn132:2.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat, went to the assembly hall, where he sat on the seat spread out,

mn132:2.4.pli: “ko nu kho, bhikkhave, upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca abhāsī”ti?
mn132:2.4.eng: “Who was inspiring the mendicants with a talk on the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night?”

mn132:2.5.pli: “Āyasmā, bhante, ānando upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca abhāsī”ti.

mn132:2.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
mn132:2.6.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,

mn132:2.7.pli: “yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca abhāsī”ti?
mn132:2.7.eng: “But in what way were you inspiring the mendicants with a talk on the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night?”

mn132:3.1.pli: “Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesiṃ samādapesiṃ samuttejesiṃ sampahaṃsesiṃ, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca abhāsiṃ—
mn132:3.1.eng: “I was doing so in this way, sir,” replied Ānanda.

mn132:3.7.eng: you clearly discern in every case.

mn132:3.10.eng: Today’s the day to keenly work—

mn132:3.11.eng: who knows, tomorrow may bring death!

mn132:3.12.eng: For there is no bargain to be struck

mn132:3.13.eng: with Death and his mighty horde.

mn132:3.14.eng: One who keenly meditates like this,

mn132:3.16.eng: that’s who has one fine night—

mn132:4.1.eng: And how do you run back to the past? …
mn132:4.1.comm: Ānanda goes on to repeat the analysis as in the previous discourse, MN 131:4.1ff.

mn132:4.2.pli: Evaṃrūpo ahosiṃ atītamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti, evaṃvedano ahosiṃ atītamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti, evaṃsañño ahosiṃ atītamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti, evaṃsaṅkhāro ahosiṃ atītamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti, evaṃviññāṇo ahosiṃ atītamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti—

mn132:5.1.eng: And how do you not run back to the past? …

mn132:5.2.pli: Evaṃrūpo ahosiṃ atītamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti, evaṃvedano ahosiṃ atītamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti, evaṃsañño ahosiṃ atītamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti, evaṃsaṅkhāro ahosiṃ atītamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti, evaṃviññāṇo ahosiṃ atītamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti—

mn132:6.1.eng: And how do you anticipate the future? …

mn132:6.2.pli: Evaṃrūpo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti, evaṃvedano siyaṃ …pe…

mn132:6.5.pli: evaṃviññāṇo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ samanvāneti—

mn132:7.1.eng: And how do you not anticipate the future? …

mn132:7.2.pli: Evaṃrūpo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti, evaṃvedano siyaṃ …pe…

mn132:7.5.pli: evaṃviññāṇo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ na samanvāneti—

mn132:8.1.eng: And how do you falter amid presently arisen phenomena? …

mn132:8.2.pli: Idha, āvuso, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto

mn132:8.3.pli: rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ, attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ;

mn132:8.7.pli: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ, attani vā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ—

mn132:8.8.pli: evaṃ kho, āvuso, paccuppannesu dhammesu saṃhīrati.

mn132:9.1.pli: Kathañca, āvuso, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati?
mn132:9.1.eng: And how do you not falter amid presently arisen phenomena? …

mn132:9.2.pli: Idha, āvuso, sutavā ariyasāvako ariyānaṃ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto sappurisānaṃ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto

mn132:9.3.pli: na rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, na rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ, na attani vā rūpaṃ, na rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ;

mn132:9.7.pli: na viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, na viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ, na attani vā viññāṇaṃ, na viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ—

mn132:9.8.pli: evaṃ kho, āvuso, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati.
mn132:9.8.eng: That’s how you don’t falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

mn132:10.15.eng: that’s who has one fine night—

mn132:11.1.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesiṃ samādapesiṃ samuttejesiṃ sampahaṃsesiṃ, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca abhāsin”ti.
mn132:11.1.eng: That’s how I was inspiring the mendicants with a talk on the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night.”

mn132:11.3.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca abhāsi:
mn132:11.3.eng: It’s good that you were inspiring the mendicants with a talk on the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night.”

mn132:13-19.1.eng: And the Buddha repeated the verses and analysis once more.

mn132:13-19.10.pli: evaṃ kho, ānanda, paccuppannesu dhammesu saṃhīrati.

mn132:13-19.11.pli: Kathañca, ānanda, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati …pe…

mn132:13-19.12.pli: evaṃ kho, ānanda, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati.

mn132:13-19.17.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn132:13-19.18.pli: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn132:13-19.18.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
